awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  An Easy RNA-Adenylation Method for Deep Sequencing of Picogram RNA Samples with High Resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to advance personalized medicine for improved treatment and prevention.  This project advances a technology to identify novel cancer-specific antigens and advances cancer immunotherapy. The proposed technology can be applied to cells in culture and solid tissues obtained by needle biopsy. Furthermore, it can be engineered into an easy-to-use system for a wide range of scientists and healthcare professionals. 

The proposed project aims to develop a versatile and cost-effective library construction technology that enables protein translation monitoring on a variety of biological samples. High throughput sequencing of RNA molecules requires the preparation of libraries. Current methods for library construction utilize adaptor ligation to the 5'- and 3'- ends of the target RNA molecules. However, ligation of adaptors is time-consuming and low-efficiency, and the resulting cDNA libraries are contaminated with cross- and self-ligation adaptor byproducts and require additional purification steps. The proposed technology relies on a novel enzyme system capable of 5’ adenylation and 3’ polyadenylation of RNA fragments. To increase the efficiency of RNA adenylation at both ends, a fusion enzyme with high enzymatic efficiency is engineered. Moreover, to reduce ligation time and increase efficiency, pre-orientated oligonucleotide adaptors will be specially designed. This project focuses on the removal of the sucrose-based centrifugation and the automation of the proposed technology, which have not been conducted previously in ribosome profiling. The proposed technology can become a method of choice for broad ribosome profiling in both laboratory and clinical settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
WHAT IS THE CENTRAL GOAL OF THE STUDY? 

The objective of this study was to develop a robust and rapid cDNA library construction technology that aims to help medical researchers and scientists from pharmaceutical companies quantify protein synthesis with superior resolution using a microscopic amount of biological samples. Given the central role of individual protein synthesis in cellular function, the proposed technology aims to foster a new view of proteomics with the possibility of discovering novel protein products. Moreover, monitoring protein synthesis in healthy and diseased cells provides mechanistic insights into disease progression and offers novel strategies for treatment and prevention.

 

WHAT WAS ACHIEVED?  

To achieve the main goal of the proposal, research on four subareas was conducted. First, sucrose-based fractionation, a time-consuming and labor-intensive procedure, was eliminated from sample processing. This was achieved without reducing the percentage usage data after sequencing. Secondly, automation was successfully introduced in the proposed library construction technology. While the library construction process is not fully automated and requires collaboration with technicians/operators, more than fifty per cent of the procedure can be done using an automation system, which enhanced reproducibility and reduced the labor intensity of the technology. Thirdly, compatibility testing of various cell lines and tissues was performed and the results showed that the proposed technology is compatible with all tested cell lines and tissues. However, optimizing is needed for a few tissue types. Lastly, the cancer translatome was established using the proposed technology, which produced a wealth of data on cancer-specific translation events.   

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2023
Modified by: Xin Shu
